meaning_mnemonic: You go down a <radical>street</radical> that cuts through a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and leads to a <radical>box</radical>. When you open the box at the end of the street, you see it's full of <kanji>image</kanji>s. Image after image. <kanji>Drawing</kanji>, <kanji>painting</kanji>, you name it. Someone must have left this box of images here.
You've seen this as a radical before, and the kanji means the same thing — <kanji>south</kanji>!
This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <radical>Lack</radical> becomes <kanji>Lack</kanji>!

Your <radical>clan</radical> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <kanji>family name</kanji>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <kanji>surname</kanji>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
A giant <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> stands above you. "I am <kanji>reason</kanji>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.

This <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>umbrella</radical>, which it's holding over its head. Strange, because trees normally like water… Turns out, this tree wasn't getting showered in water, but in dollar <kanji>bill</kanji>s instead.
The <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>clan</radical> are a group of <kanji>people</kanji>. They are the <kanji>people</kanji> of a <kanji>nation</kanji>.

While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you take your <radical>sword</radical> and cut out an <kanji>area</kanji> on the ground.  You carefully cut all the <kanji>side</kanji>s as you go. This area's all yours now!

When you take your <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>measurement</radical>s, you realize they're too short, so you <kanji>attach</kanji> things to them to make the measurements more impressive. Attach some heels to the shoes, then attach another head on top of theirs. There — perfect measurements thanks to these attachments.

The <radical>lion</radical> drops a <radical>drop</radical> of saliva onto this <radical>person</radical> <kanji>from</kanji> above. The person is in a much worse place <kanji>compared with</kanji> where they were before, <kanji>since</kanji> they only just recently fell into this pit.
That <radical>slide</radical> is your <radical>husband</radical>'s only <kanji>fault</kanji>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
Your heart has a slide running through it because you want to be certain that the blood is flowing in and out of it smoothly. Given how important this is, you want to be absolutely certain.

You're flying in a <radical>jet</radical>. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<kanji>Not yet</kanji>! Not yet! NOT YET!"

This kanji uses a modified <radical>jet</radical> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <kanji>end</kanji> of the earth.
Next to the <radical>tree</radical>, a <radical>lid</radical> is put on your <radical>father</radical>. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new <kanji>school</kanji>."

The <radical>leaf</radical> shaped like an <radical>eye</radical> only grows in <radical>winter</radical>. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the <kanji>summer</kanji>.
You have two <radical>bow</radical>s but they're both covered in <radical>ice</radical>. This has made them very <kanji>weak</kanji>.

The <radical>sun</radical> is used in a <radical>temple</radical> to tell <kanji>time</kanji>. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."

This also can mean <kanji>o' clock</kanji>, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.
The <radical>thread</radical> that ties you to your <radical>clan</radical> is <kanji>paper</kanji>. Your papers, that is.

What you <radical>say</radical> to <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself), you decide to <kanji>write down</kanji>. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to <kanji>record</kanji> these important thoughts in some way.

There's a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>mama</radical> carrying a <radical>task</radical> she needs to get done. You see her <kanji>pass through</kanji>, hurrying by to get that task done.

There's a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and <radical>mustache</radical>, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how <kanji>tall</kanji> and <kanji>expensive</kanji> you are.

You keep your <radical>bow</radical> <radical>private</radical> because it's made of <radical>insect</radical>s, meaning it's extremely <kanji>strong</kanji>. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for super strong bows. That's why you have to keep this one private — it's simply too strong to let others get ahold of.

A <radical>teacher</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is happiest because they get to <kanji>teach</kanji>! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>village</radical> is the <kanji>reason</kanji> he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.

Sew <radical>thread</radical> through your <radical>top hat</radical> and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a <kanji>group</kanji> of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
Your <radical>boat</radical> has <radical>fins</radical> and a <radical>mouth</radical>! It's still a <kanji>boat</kanji> though.
Use a <radical>scooter</radical> to travel the <radical>circumference</radical> of the world and it will take you a full <kanji>week</kanji>. Seven whole days!
When <radical>rain</radical> falls on <radical>Wolverine</radical>, it turns to <kanji>snow</kanji>. He's so emotionally distant and cold that the rain freezes into snow as soon as it gets near him.
The radical <radical>fish</radical> and the kanji <kanji>fish</kanji> are exactly the same!
The <radical>bird</radical> radical and the <kanji>bird</kanji> kanji are the same!
The radical <radical>yellow</radical> and the kanji <kanji>yellow</kanji> are exactly the same!
The radical <radical>black</radical> and the kanji <kanji>black</kanji> are exactly the same.

You look at a <radical>table</radical> and notice it is being used as a <radical>slide</radical> by <radical>insect</radical>s to launch themselves into the <kanji>wind</kanji>.

This kanji can also mean <kanji>style</kanji>. To remember this, consider how styles can change quickly, just like the <kanji>wind</kanji>!
The <radical>sun</radical> in the <radical>center</radical> of the sky gives off its light, which <kanji>reflect</kanji>s off of everything around it.

The <radical>elephant</radical> radical and the <kanji>elephant</kanji> kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: <kanji>phenomenon</kanji>. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too.
Under the <radical>canopy</radical>, you use a <radical>tree</radical> for your <kanji>floor</kanji>. It also becomes your <kanji>bed</kanji>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
